body:
We've discussed before why the `install()` method shouldn't be accessing the Internet.  Reasons include:
1. Doesn't work from machines without Internet access.
2. Messes up Spack's tarball caching.
3. Obscures missing dependencies (eg, some packages auto-download from PyPI)
4. Can result in software that's installed in weird ways (eg, auto-downloaded packages are invisible to Spack).

Is there a way Spack can run the install() method in a sandbox that lacks Internet access?
title: Sandbox install() from the Internet
